body: LEAD: A volatile mixture of deep-seated racial animosities, starkly segregated environments and fear of economic change may have fostered the murder of a 16-year-old black youth in Bensonhurst last month, say social scientists who have studied race relations in large cities like New York. title: Hatred and Social Isolation May Spur Acts of Racial Violence, Experts Say

body: LEAD: The killing of a black teen-ager Wednesday night in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn is but the most searing example of what sociologists and civil rights groups say is a renewed and rising tide of racial intolerance among teen-agers and young adults across the country. title: A New Generation of Racism Is Seen

body: LEAD: To the Editor: To the Editor: As a longtime resident of Flatbush, I was interested in your feature on the community on June 6. Obviously, Flatbush has changed a lot since I moved away from there in 1945, but has it changed its boundaries? title: Flatbush

body: LEAD: Fort Hamilton's batteries of big iron-barreled guns facing Lower New York Bay are long gone and its days as a battle-ready Army fort are past, but this 177-acre Brooklyn citadel remains heavily armed with history. title: Out of New York's Military Past

body: LEAD: Six incumbents have been re-elected to a Brooklyn school board that has become, its critics contend, a symbol of what can occur when a local board subordinates educational interests to political concerns. body: LEAD: UNTIL spring, most New Yorkers would probably prefer to forget that there even is an outdoors, a place where chill winds nip mercilessly at bundled-up strollers. But for hardy urban explorers, New York is more than just an agglomeration of warm buildings. About one-seventh of the city's 303.7 square miles is parkland, and in it one can hike
title: The Great Outdoors, Within City Limits
